title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #589: Points in General Position**

Let g(n) be the minimum guaranteed general position subset size in any n-point set with no 4 collinear.

**Known Bounds:**
- Lower: n^(1/2)·log n (Füredi 1991)
- Upper: n^(5/6+o(1)) (Balogh-Solymosi 2018)

**Erdős's Belief (WRONG):** g(n) = Ω(n)
mathContext: The exact exponent remains open - somewhere between 1/2 and 5/6.

title: Collinearity Definitions
content:
**Collinear3 p q r:**

Three points are collinear if they lie on a common line. Uses determinant criterion.

**Collinear4 p q r s:**

Four points are collinear if all lie on a common line (pairwise collinearity of triples).

title: General and Almost General Position
content:
**InGeneralPosition S:**

No three points of S are collinear.

**InAlmostGeneralPosition S:**

No four points of S are collinear (but three may be).

The problem: extract general position from almost general position.

title: The Function g(n)
content:
**g(n):**

The MINIMUM over all n-point sets in almost general position of the MAXIMUM general position subset size.

This is the worst-case guarantee: ANY set with no 4 collinear has a subset of at least g(n) points with no 3 collinear.
mathContext: g(n) captures the worst-case extractable general position subset.

title: Erdős's Belief (Disproved)
content:
**ErdosBelief, erdos_belief_false:**

Erdős originally thought g(n) = Ω(n) - linear growth.

This was DISPROVED. The density Hales-Jewett theorem implies g(n) = o(n).
mathContext: Erdős's intuition was wrong on this problem.

title: Greedy Lower Bound
content:
**greedy_lower_bound, trivial_lower_bound:**

g(n) ≥ c·√n for some constant c > 0.

**Algorithm:** Pick points one by one, always choosing a point that doesn't form a collinear triple with any two already chosen.

This is the 'trivial' bound improved by Füredi.

title: Füredi's Results (1991)
content:
**furedi_lower_bound, furedi_upper_bound:**

- Lower: g(n) ≥ c·√n·log n (improves greedy by log factor)
- Upper: g(n) = o(n) (sublinear growth)

The upper bound uses the density Hales-Jewett theorem.
mathContext: Published in SIAM J. Discrete Math.

title: Density Hales-Jewett Connection
content:
**density_hales_jewett, dhj_implies_sublinear:**

The DHJ theorem (Furstenberg-Katznelson 1991): For every δ > 0 and k ≥ 2, there exists N such that any δ-dense subset of [k]^N contains a combinatorial line.

This implies g(n) = o(n) via embedding arguments.
mathContext: A deep result in Ramsey theory/ergodic theory.

title: Balogh-Solymosi (2018)
content:
**balogh_solymosi_2018:**

g(n) ≤ n^(5/6+o(1))

Proved using the **container method** (Saxton-Thomason, Balogh-Morris-Samotij).

This was the FIRST application of containers to discrete geometry.

**Construction:** Random n-element subset of large 3D grid, projected to 2D.

title: Current Best Bounds
content:
**current_bounds:**

n^(1/2)·log n ≪ g(n) ≤ n^(5/6+o(1))

The gap between exponents 1/2 and 5/6 remains open.

title: Generalized Problem
content:
**g_kl(k, l, n):**

For k > l ≥ 3, the generalized function where we extract l-general position from k-general position.

The original problem is g(n) = g_{4,3}(n).

title: Open Questions
content:
**ExactGrowthOpen, balogh_solymosi_conjecture:**

**Main open question:** What is the exact exponent α such that g(n) = Θ(n^α)?

Is it 1/2, 5/6, or something in between?

Balogh-Solymosi suggest 5/6 might be correct.

title: Problem Summary
content:
**erdos_589_summary:**

| Aspect | Result |
|--------|--------|
| Question | Estimate g(n) |
| Erdős's belief | g(n) = Ω(n) (WRONG) |
| Lower bound | c·√n·log n (Füredi) |
| Upper bound | n^(5/6+o(1)) (Balogh-Solymosi) |
| Key tools | DHJ, Container method |
| Status | Partially resolved |
